repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
No way to deduplicate values in a list in-place

Solution:
Add `vim.list.unique()`

comment_data.body: Let's call this `key` (or `keyfn`). That is the python convention and it's planned for many more cases in Nvim stdlib.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

comment_data.body: In fact python leverages `__hash__` combined with `set()` for this sort of stuff.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

comment_data.body: Even though it mutates the list in-place, returning the result is a good pattern, because it allows the caller to opt-in to "immutable" behavior via `deepcopy()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2092,6 +2092,35 @@ vim.islist({t})                                                 *vim.islist()*
     See also: ~
       • |vim.isarray()|
 
+vim.list.unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list.unique()*
+    Removes duplicate values from a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Only the first occurrence of each value is kept. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.
+
+    Accepts an optional `hash` argument that if provided is called for each
+    value in the list to compute a hash key for uniqueness comparison. This is
+    useful for deduplicating table values or complex objects.
+
+    Example: >lua
+
+        local t = {1, 2, 2, 3, 1}
+        vim.list.unique(t)
+        -- t is now {1, 2, 3}
+
+        local t = { {id=1}, {id=2}, {id=1} }
+        vim.list.unique(t, function(x) return x.id end)
+        -- t is now { {id=1}, {id=2} }
+<
+
+    Parameters: ~
+      • {t}     (`any[]`)
+      • {hash}  (`fun(x: T): any??`) Optional hash function to determine
+                uniqueness of values
+
+    Return: ~
+        (`any[]`) The deduplicated list

comment_data.body: It's a hash, but this is only about the naming convention for the parameter. Python sorted() for example takes a key arg: https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#sorted
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

comment_data.body: np. I'm happy to relent bike shedding if it means we can leverage other docs and conventions.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2134,6 +2134,35 @@ vim.list_slice({list}, {start}, {finish})                   *vim.list_slice()*
     Return: ~
         (`any[]`) Copy of table sliced from start to finish (inclusive)
 
+vim.list_unique({t}, {hash})                               *vim.list_unique()*

comment_data.body: nit/non-blocker: may want to start a `list_spec.lua`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1260,6 +1260,27 @@ describe('lua stdlib', function()
     eq({ 2 }, exec_lua [[ return vim.list_extend({}, {2;a=1}, -1, 2) ]])
   end)
 
+  it('vim.list.unique', function()

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    Accepts an optional `key` argument that if provided is called for each
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2092,6 +2092,35 @@ vim.islist({t})                                                 *vim.islist()*
     See also: ~
       • |vim.isarray()|
 
+vim.list.unique({t}, {key})                                *vim.list.unique()*
+    Removes duplicate values from a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Only the first occurrence of each value is kept. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.
+
+    Accepts an optional `hash` argument that if provided is called for each

comment_regular_data.body:
Copying my comment here for reference:

I just came across this, and there are (at least) three issues with `vim.fn.uniq`:
1. polyvalent return type (deduped list or `0` if input is not a list), which confuses luals and emmyluals.
2. inability to modify the list in-place due to the well-documented limitations of the bridge (i.e., unlike `uniq(list)`, `vim.fn.uniq(list)` does nothing).
3. `uniq` only removes _adjacent_ duplicates, so `vim.fn.uniq({'a', 'b', 'a', 'b'})` returns the list unchanged.

Since deduplicating lists is a fairly common task, together these do add up to a compelling argument for adding a `vim.list_dedup` (name TBD) to the stdlib.

Since we are going to introduce `vim.list` anyway, can we add this there instead of adding another `list_foo` function? Though `vim.list` will be a wrapper around `vim.iter`, but that doesn't preclude other additions.

All of the existing `list_foo` functions will be deprecated and/or migrated to `vim.list.*`.

> Though vim.list will be a wrapper around vim.iter, but that doesn't preclude other additions.

What kind of wrapper? You're aware I'm not comfortable with some of the design and implementation decisions in `vim.iter()`.

> What kind of wrapper? You're aware I'm not comfortable with some of the design and implementation decisions in `vim.iter()`

The point of `vim.list` wrapper is to be more appropriate for lists, as we've discussed awhile ago. (In fact, the idea is largely a compromise in your favor...) And it's orthogonal for the near-term decision of not adding more `list_xx` tech debt meanwhile.

> The point of vim.list wrapper is to be more appropriate for lists, as we've discussed awhile ago. And it's orthogonal for the near-term decision of not adding more list_xx tech debt meanwhile.

What does it need to wrap though? I'd expect all functions to be better if written directly, rather than using `vim.iter()` which does an unconditional pass on the input. For the most part using `vim.iter()` is just a different style (which is heavier with anonymous functions). It only becomes really beneficial when you construct pipelines.
That is orthogonal, why are we debating it right now?

I'll only invest time on this if we're aligned on the path, I'd like `vim.list` to be conceptually independent to `vim.iter`. I'm also genuinely asking in case there are some functions that actually need `vim.iter()` for whatever reason.

> I'd like `vim.list` to be conceptually independent to `vim.iter`

My thought is that `vim.list()` or `vim.list.<something>` should be an interface that starts an iter pipeline that forces `vim.iter` to treat stuff as list-like (and skips the vim.iter "auto detection", which is a performance improvement). That's a pretty limited interface and doesn't block whatever module-level things we want on `vim.list.*`.

I'm hoping we don't need to introduce an entirely different `vim.List` container. If we're aligned on that then I think it will be smooth sailing.

> I'm hoping we don't need to introduce an entirely different vim.List container. If we're aligned on that then I think it will be smooth sailing.

I don't want any kind of list containers. `vim.list()` should just operate on any Lua table, it is up to the user to pass a table which abides to the interface. Similar to how `ipairs` operates on a list, but passing a table with a hash part is still well defined.

For example here `vim.list.unique({1,2,3,4,4,4,5, field=1})` works fine and produces `{1,2,3,4,5,field=1}`, as the hash part of the table is completely ignored.

In fact I'll add a test for that.

> My thought is that vim.list() or vim.list.<something> should be an interface that starts an iter pipeline that forces vim.iter to treat stuff as list-like

Not a fan of this. I'd like everything in `vim.list` to operate on tables, not iterables.

The `vim.iter` auto-detection should be removed, and the functions it accepts should always include the key. That would fix all my issues with it.

This LGTM, let's include the motivations mentioned in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35067#issuecomment-3118010827 in the commit message.

> For example here `vim.list.unique({1,2,3,4,4,4,5, field=1})` works fine and produces `{1,2,3,4,5,field=1}`, as the hash part of the table is completely ignored.

That is cool, and feels like a good general practice (where possible) for our list/dict/table stdlib.

> The `vim.iter` auto-detection should be removed,

Maybe, but it doesn't really matter as long as the caller can opt-in to list/dict behavior & skip the auto-detection?

> and the functions it accepts should always include the key. 

Not 100% sure what this means.

> Not 100% sure what this means.

From #8941

> it really wasn't obvious to me that the map function only takes a single argument, unlike ipairs which gives you both the index and the value.

> let's include the motivations mentioned in [#35067 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35067#issuecomment-3118010827) in the commit message.

This wasn't done :( 

> it really wasn't obvious to me that the map function only takes a single argument, unlike ipairs which gives you both the index and the value.

I definitely agree with that.

> This wasn't done :(

Eek, sorry. Forgot about that.
